Given the abundance of gene expression data across multiple tissues (Chen et al., 2018; Mancuso et al., 2018; GTEx Consortium et al., 2017; Gamazon et al., 2020), one effective method for identifying underlying biological processes is the transcription-wide association study (TWAS). TWAS integrates expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to offer a mechanistic explanation for Genome-Wide Association Study (GWAS) findings. This approach assesses whether disruptions in gene regulatory mechanisms mediate the relationship between genetic variants and human diseases (Gamazon et al., 2021; Hormozdiari et al., 2018; Gusev et al., 2019; GTEx Consortium et al., 2017), and has proven successful in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level (Wainberg et al., 2021; Hormozdiari et al., 2019; Wainberg et al., 2018) as well as in disease-risk prediction through polygenic scores (Choi et al., 2021) and drug repurposing efforts (Krishnan et al., 2017). However, it is important to note that TWAS operates at the single gene level and may not capture more intricate interactions at the network level.
